title: Guinea pig ice cream is on sale in Quito, Ecuador
text:
An ice cream maker in Quito, Ecaudor is earning popularity with her guinea pig flavor — which is made with actual rodent meat.

Ice cream stall owner María del Carmen Pilapaña opened up shop in September, and there she sells just three flavors: beetle, mushroom, and guinea pig.

Pilapaña admitted to the AP that her family thought she was 'crazy' to take on the venture, but that guinea pig ice cream is now her top seller.

Something different! María del Carmen Pilapaña is earning popularity with her guinea pig ice cream flavor — which is made with actual rodent meat

Not for petting! Guinea pig is actually a traditional meat dish in some Latin American countries, including Colombia, Peru, and Bolivia, where it's called 'cuy'

Scoop it up! Pilapaña admitted to the AP that her family thought she was 'crazy' to take on the venture, but that guinea pig ice cream is now her top seller

Guinea pig is actually a traditional meat dish in some Latin American countries, including Colombia, Peru, and Bolivia, where it's called 'cuy.'

It can be found at many restaurants, including higher-end establishments, and tastes similar to chicken.

In Ecuador, people typically cook guinea pigs with salt and serve them with potatoes and peanut sauce.

But Pilapaña said that when she had the idea to incorporate it into a frozen dessert, not everyone believed it was a good idea.

'My family and my husband thought I was crazy. They didn't think anyone would like these ice creams, but now they're our main product,' said Pilapaña, who attended free training courses for entrepreneurs when she dreamed up the project.

She was challenged to do something innovative and, after six months of testing, she starting selling her range of ice creams at the beginning of September.

On the menu: Cuy can be found at many restaurants and tastes similar to chicken. In Ecuador, people typically cook guinea pigs with salt and serve them with potatoes and peanut sauce

In the kitchen: Pilapaña concentrates the guinea pig flavor by cooking and preparing a pâté from the animal's flesh. She then adds milk or cream and refrigerates the concoction

Growing popularity: Her shop is just two tables in an open area lined with dentists' clinics and other business, but despite its small, not-so-flashy setup, demand is growing

Something buzz-worthy: She has other flavors, but her guinea pig ice cream is her most popular product

Pilapaña concentrates the guinea pig flavor by cooking and preparing a pâté from the animal's flesh. She then adds milk or cream and refrigerates the concoction until it has the rough consistency of ice cream.

Her shop is just two tables in an open area lined with dentists' clinics and other business, but despite its small, not-so-flashy setup, demand is growing.

Every week, the entrepreneur prepares 150 servings ($1 for a cone) of guinea pig ice cream.

She also makes 40 servings of ice cream flavored with beetles, which also traditionally eaten as a salty snack, and a smaller amount of mushroom ice cream.

The beetle and mushroom ice creams include fruits such as pineapple and passion fruit. Beetle ice cream has a slight aroma of wet earth.

But the guinea pig ice cream is the most popular, and customers are singing its praises.

Serving up smiles: Every week, the entrepreneur prepares 150 servings ($1 for a cone) of guinea pig ice cream

Variety: She also makes 40 servings of ice cream flavored with beetles, which also traditionally eaten as a salty snack, and a smaller amount of mushroom ice cream

What's next? Pilapaña has new flavors in mind including crab, chicken, and pork

'I was suspicious, but it was tasty,' said Marlene Franco, a 78-year-old retiree who tried a scoop at a stall next to a highway linking the Ecuadorian capital of Quito to the city of Sangolqui.

Ants, cicadas and worms are used to make some desserts — often chocolate-infused ones — in parts of Latin America.

Carolina Páez, director of the anthropology school of the Catholic University in Quito, isn't surprised that the cuy ice cream has taken off.

'The guinea pig is a very important ancient food in Andean indigenous societies, especially for its high protein content,' she said.

Other cultures eat various types of animals, Páez said, 'so there is no reason to be amazed that Ecuadorians eat guinea pigs, even in ice cream.'

For Pilapaña, guinea pig ice cream is just the beginning. She has new flavors in mind: crab, chicken, and pork.

'Seeing how my business is picking up, I'm sure I'll do well,' she said.

Interesting... Oscar Mayer collaborated with il laboratorio del gelato on a hot dog ice cream sandwich this summer

Salty! New Jersey creamery Windy Brow Farms went viral for its Taylor ham-flavored ice cream

While guinea pig ice cream certainly seems bizarre, it's just the latest example of meat being used in ice cream.

Over the summer, in honor of National Ice Cream Sandwich Day, Oscar Mayer debuted the 'Ice Dog Sandwich' in partnership with the New York City gelato shop il laboratorio del gelato.

The ice cream sandwich was made with a hot dog-infused ice cream that included real pieces of hot dog, which sat side-by-side with a mustard-flavored ice cream between two cookies.

In 2018, Windy Brow Farms in Fredon Township, New Jersey went viral for its Taylor ham flavor, which was made with two pounds of the meat — also called pork roll — per 2.5 gallons of ice cream.
description: María del Carmen Pilapaña makes guinea pig ice cream flavor at her small shop in Quito. Guinea pig is actually a traditional meat dish in some Latin American countries.
